Graphical abstract To investigate the comprehensive understanding of the thermodynamic growth mechanisms for heterostructure and the relationship between interface design and the D-band center as well as catalytic performance was established. The polysulfide shuttle effect critically hinders lithium-sulfur (LiS) battery development, therefore, the design of heterogeneous interface engineering with “adsorption-catalysis” functions for polysulfide conversion has garnered considerable attention. However, the exploration of the intricate relationship between key electronic properties and catalytic activity at such interfaces remains a challenge. Additionally, a comprehensive understanding of the thermodynamic growth mechanisms for heterostructure materials is lacking. Herein, a Ni-based homologous structure was precisely constructed via thermodynamic control, with a specific focus on optimizing the interface design. The theoretical results show that the heterostructures with adjustable composition realize the appropriate upward shift to the D-band, improving the affinity towards polysulfide, and further reducing the reaction energy barrier. On this basis, the relationship between interface design and the D-band center, as well as catalytic performance, was established. Specifically, M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 accomplishes the electron enrichment at the interface, supporting the further diffusion of polysulfides, and lowering the LiS bond energy, performing the bidirectional catalytic transformation of polysulfides. As a result, the LiS batteries with the cathode of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S deliver rate performances of discharge capacity of 514 mA h g−1 at 5.0 C. This understanding of the D-band and interfacial design provides a framework for LiS catalyst optimization. Keywords Lithium-sulfur battery Heterostructure D-band Interfacial design 1 Introduction The development of electric vehicles and portable electronics has increased the demand for energy storage systems [1,2]. However, the energy density of the most advanced lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries has been getting close to the limit [3,4]. With a high specific capacity of 1675 mA h g−1 and theoretical energy density of 2600 W h kg−1, lithium-sulfur (LiS) batteries are regarded as one of the most promising battery technologies [5–7]. However, the shuttle behavior of dissolved polysulfides (LiPSs) during the reaction causes the loss of active substances and the rapid decay of capacity, which seriously hinders their further application [8–10]. Numerous catalysts have been successfully employed as sulfur host materials to speed up the conversion of polysulfides [11–13]. Some theories, including D-band theory [14], electric-field theory [15], and crystal-field theory [16], were applied to optimize the catalyst design, enhancing the reaction kinetics towards the LiS system [17–19]. In particular, D-band theory enhances the understanding of the catalytic mechanism. It connects polysulfide activity with the fundamental electronic properties of the catalyst [20]. Actually, the D-band theory defines the structure-reaction connection of the catalyst by connecting the surface chemical characteristics to the surface electronic structure of the metal-containing surface [21,22], while the intrinsic structure of the catalyst is further determined by the reaction thermodynamics [23,24]. It is necessary to rationalize the activity trend of the electrocatalyst with thermodynamic strategy as the center, establishing a connection with the D-band. Recently, multiple engineering [25,26] has been used to achieve the sensible control of the D-band towards the catalyst and to further develop an electrocatalyst with high catalytic activity, including doping engineering [27,28], phase engineering [29,30], and heterostructure engineering [31–33]. Among them, the heterostructures have achieved brilliant performance in LiS cells through multi-component coupling design as multi-functional catalysts, such as COF/MXene [34], Cu3P/Cu2O [35], and NiS2-CoS2 [36]. Most heterogeneous structures, as multifunctional catalysts, couple the synergies of different components, accelerating the transformation of polysulfides to a certain extent [37,38]. Considering the metal-based catalysts [39,40], especially Ni, the electronic structure of which delivers similar properties to precious metals, as well as possesses the unfilled D-orbital electrons. This feature enables high tunability and strong adsorption and activation of the reactant molecules on the surface of the nickel-based catalyst. Furthermore, the Fe atom delivers a distinct structure with Ni, which could potentially modify the electronic state of Ni even more, demonstrating the potential to construct multifunctional catalysts with heterostructures [41,42]. However, despite these advances, the mechanism behind interfacial catalysis remains unidentified, while the heterogeneous interface has long been thought to as the active site of charge transfer and heterophase reaction [43,44]. Using a heterostructure built by various thermodynamic factors [45,46] to integrate band structure with heterogeneous engineering and interfacial electronic characteristics with catalytic activity is crucial for designing effective electrocatalysts. Herein, a link between heterostructure interface design and D-band center was established as well as catalytic performance. The change in Fe concentration directly affects the thermodynamic growth stability of different phases in the Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 system. In addition, the designed interface facilitates electron enrichment and transfer between Ni and Fe, generating an internal electric field that accelerates the catalytic conversion of polysulfides. Crucially, the formation of the interface modulates the D-band of the catalyst, which avoids the passivation on catalyst caused by excessive adsorption, further reducing the reaction energy barrier. The longer LiS bond on the Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 aided in the desorption and dissolution of Li2S. As a result, M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S as the host material exhibits minimal Li2S2 disproportionation, which directionally promotes the deposition and oxidation process of Li2S. Based on this, M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 provides effective long-term cycling stability with a capacity attenuation rate of 0.062% per cycle after 500 cycles at 1.0 C in LiS systems. And M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 continues to exhibit outstanding electrochemical performance even when exposed to rate capability and high sulfur loading. 2 Results and discussion The synthesis process of Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 on porous carbon nanofibers is shown in Fig. 1 a. In short, the Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 was prepared via the peocess of electrospinning and then calcining. The heterogeneous structure of different components can be obtained by controlling the amount of the precursor Fe metal salt. To create the various samples, the mass ratio of Ni/Fe was varied from 2/1, 4/1, 6.5/1 and 9/1, resulting products were designated as Ni3Fe, L-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7, M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 and H-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7, respectively. Firstly, we explored the thermodynamic growth process of the heterostructure with varying Fe content. The crystal structures of several samples were first examined using X-ray diffraction (XRD). Fig. 1b shows the existence of Ni3Fe and Ni3ZnC0.7 from diffraction peaks. The diffraction peaks at 44.2°, 51.5° and 75.8° correspond to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of the Ni3Fe phase. And the peaks at 42.7°and 49.7° assigned to the (111) and (200) crystal planes of Ni3ZnC0.7. It is worth noting that when the Fe content grows, the distinctive peaks that correspond to Ni3ZnC0.7 progressively vanish, showing that Ni preferentially coordinates with Fe to produce Ni3Fe alloy, subsequently generated to Ni3ZnC0.7. In brief, Fe preferentially coordinates with Ni to form the Ni3Fe alloy, followed by Zn reacting to form Ni3ZnC0.7. The formation of Ni3ZnC0.7 is strongly correlated with the Ni concentration in the precursor, as insufficient Ni concentration prevents its participation in the reaction. The microstructure of materials was examined using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). As shown in Fig. 1c and Fig. S1 (Supporting information), the nanoparticles grow on the long-range tubular shape carbon nanofibers. Simultaneously, the morphology and structural integrity are maintained even at higher Fe contents. TEM with different magnifications in Fig. 1d and Fig. S2 shows that the fibers are around 100 nm in width, and the interior is filled with abundant nanoparticles. The heterogeneous interface between various materials is visible in the HRTEM image (Fig. 1e), with a lattice spacing of 0.206 and 0.183 nm (Fig. 1f, g), which correspond to the Ni3Fe (111) and Ni3ZnC0.7 (200) planes, respectively. Moreover, Fig. S3 supplemented the corresponding SAED patterns of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7. The diffraction rings point to the (111) and (111) crystal planes of Ni3Fe and Ni3ZnC0.7, indicating the successful synthesis of the Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7. After that, the EDS technique demonstrates the uniform distribution of these elements within M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 (Fig. 1h–l). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to further examine the elemental composition and surface chemical state of these as-obtained samples. The distinctive peaks of several elements were seen in the overall XPS survey spectra of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 in Fig. S4. Two distinct peaks at 1022 and 1045 eV should be attributed to Zn 2p 3/2 and Zn 2p 1/2 (Fig. S5). Furthermore, the valence variations towards the key elements of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 and the Ni3Fe were contrasted in Fig. 2 a, b. For the Ni 2p spectra in M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7, two peaks at 853.1 and 872.6 eV were attributed to Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2 in the Ni0 valence state [47,48]. Two distinct peaks at 855.3 and 872.6 eV should be attributed to Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2 in the Ni2+ valence state. The comparison of the Ni 2p spectrum of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 and Ni3Fe further shows that the formation of heterogeneous structures makes M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 shift towards the lower binding energy, suggesting that the Ni is in the electron-abundance state. Two peaks at 707.8 and 720.9 eV are identified as Fe0 2p 3/2 and Fe0 2p 1/2, respectively, in the Fe 2p spectrum [49,50]. And the other two peaks at 711.5 and 724.6 eV, together with two satellite peaks, are identified as Fe3+ 2p 3/2 and Fe3+ 2p 1/2, respectively. In contrast, after forming a heterogeneous structure, the Fe 2p orbital shifts toward a higher binding energy, indicating its electron-deficient state. In this instance, the Fe and Ni peak shifts in M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 show that Ni3Fe can donate electrons in M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7, allowing electrons to transfer from Ni3Fe to Ni3ZnC0.7. Then the work functions of different samples are compared in Fig. 2c–e. Obviously, the work function of Ni3Fe (5.02 eV) is clearly less than that of Ni3ZnC0.7 (5.24 eV). In addition, the lowest work function (4.51 eV) is shown after the formation of Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7, which might be attributed to the alignment of Fermi levels upon contact and the formation of a dipole layer brought by the charge transfer of heterostructures. Further, the energy band change diagram of Ni3Fe and Ni3ZnC0.7 before and after contact is shown in Fig. 2f. Due to the disparity in the work function, electrons will move from the Ni3Fe to Ni3ZnC0.7 until the thermodynamic equilibrium state is attained and the Fermi level is equal [51,52]. The differential charge density in Fig. 2g is used to further investigate the electron state at the heterogeneous interface, while cyan indicates the loss of electrons and yellow represents the gain of electrons. Numerous electrons are enriched at the heterogeneous interface, which further modifies the electronic structure at the active site and quickens the kinetics of charge transfer. In addition, the charge density difference of Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 indicates that Fe loses 0.417 e− while Ni receives electrons in Ni3Fe. After the formation of the heterostructure, both Fe and Ni lose electrons in the Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7, while carbon receives 0.859 e− (Table S1). The transfer of electrons leads to the redistribution of charges at the interface. This redistribution generates electron-rich regions in Ni3ZnC0.7 and hole-rich regions in Ni3Fe, resulting in a shift in the Fermi level. Overall, adding Fe results in the formation of various heterogeneous structures, and the creation of heterogeneous interfaces facilitates electron transmission and optimizes the electronic structure. The electrochemical performance was further investigated by assembling L-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S, M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S, H-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S and Ni3Fe/S batteries. The electrochemical characteristics at 0.2 C were first compared in more detail (Fig. 3 a). M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S cell delivers an initial discharge capacity of 1128 mA h g−1 and still has a discharge capacity of 942 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles. In comparison, Ni3Fe/S has a low initial capacity of 1070 mA h g−1, and the capacity after cycling only reaches 821 mA h g−1. The galvanostatic discharge–charge profiles of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S-based cells at 1.0 C (Fig. S6) exhibited the highest discharge capacity as well as the minimum overpotential at about 2.0 V in the reduction process, compared to L-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S (800 mA h g−1) and H-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S (911 mA h g−1). Furthermore, M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S delivered the lowest polarization potential (0.26 V) in Fig. S7, while others showed significant potential polarizations and capacity deteriorations. The rate performance is then contrasted under various current densities. The M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S-based cell had rate performances of 1095, 962, 780, 657 and 514 mA h g−1 at 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 3.0 and 5.0 C, respectively. Fig. 3b shows that at a current density of 5 C, Ni3Fe/M-Ni3ZnC0.7 still exhibits relatively high Coulombic efficiency, indicating the improved utilization rate of active substances. The electrochemical characteristics of Ni3Fe are further altered by the creation of a heterogeneous interface, whereas H-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S performs worse than M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S because of the excessively powerful adsorption ability towards polysulfides. Fig. 3c shows the charge–discharge curve at different current densities of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S-based cells, and two obvious reduction platforms could still be identified at 3.0 C, indicating its effectiveness in promoting polysulfide conversion at high current densities, which should be attributed to the enhancement of heterogeneous interfaces. Additionally, the trailing phenomenon at 0.5 C was attributed to the irreversible reduction of LiNO3 [53,54]. When LiNO3 is used as an additive or a co-salt of the electrolyte, excessively low discharge cut-off voltage will lead to an irreversible reduction of part of LiNO3 to generate the SEI on the surface of the Li anode. The charge–discharge curves in Fig. S8 after cycling also indicate that the formation of SEI only occurs in the initial cyclic process and gradually disappears as the cycle proceeds. Further comparison of the capacity retention rate of the high voltage platform (Fig. 3d) shows that M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S-based cells have a higher retention rate under different current densities. Additional testing was done in Fig. 3g on the long-term stability of cells with various electrode configurations. M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S-based cells deliver a decent reversibility of 606 mA h g−1 over 500 cycles with a capacity attenuation of 0.062% per cycle. In contrast, Ni3Fe/S-based cells only show a capacity of 500 cycles decayed to 501 mA h g−1, revealing poor cycle stability. In addition, during the initial cycle, the excessive adsorption behavior on Ni3Fe of polysulfides passivated the catalyst surface, which increased polarization, resulting in a slowdown in kinetics and a rapid decrease in capacity. The electrochemical properties of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S-based cells with high sulfur loading were examined at a current density of 0.2 C. Fig. 3e demonstrates that M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S cell still hold an areal capacity of ∼3.5 mA h cm−2 under the sulfur loading of ∼4.6 mg cm−2 after 50 cycles (E/S ratio of 10 µl/mg). The M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S electrode was able to keep the LED lights in Fig. 3f lighted for several minutes, demonstrating the robustness and usefulness. Simultaneously, the advantages of the designed M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 are highlighted by the comparison with other cathode materials (Fig. 3h and Table S2), proving that the performance of the structure is further improved by the construction of the heterogeneous interface. Then the assembled cells were disassembled after cycling to determine the failure mechanism of the heterogeneous structure. Through SEM comparison of the cycled lithium metal anode (Fig. S9), the surfaces of all samples have severe corrosion with different degrees, while the surface of the Li anode from M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S-based cells has a much smoother surface, indicating that M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 improved the polysulfide reaction kinetics. In addition, the condition of separators after cycling is shown in Fig. S10. The separator from the M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S-based cell is relatively colorless, while other samples show a yellowish surface. In addition, the capacity contribution of pure M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 during the redox process was further compared. Fig. S11 indicates that the capacity contribution of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 can be disregarded. In summary, the electrochemical performance is further enhanced by the creation of heterogeneous interfaces. To better investigate the principle behind the catalytic behavior of different heterogeneous materials, the kinetic behavior throughout the chemical reaction process is further studied. Firstly, the adsorption behavior of polysulfide by different materials was investigated. A diluted polysulfide solution was used to further observe the improved adsorption behavior of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 in Fig. S12. It is demonstrated that the adsorption ability of various polysulfides is further improved when the Ni3Fe content rises. Adding different content of Fe effectively modifies the adsorption capability towards polysulfides. Ni3Fe in particular demonstrated an excessive adsorption action, which further passivated the surface of the catalyst. M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 showed moderate adsorption capacity, which further reduced the polysulfide shuttle. Additionally, the UV–vis spectrum in Fig. 4 a demonstrates that the distinctive absorbance of S6 2− constantly declines as the addition of Fe content increases, supporting the aforementioned result. The interaction between M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 and Li2S6 was verified by the comparison of XPS before and after adsorption in Fig. 4b [55]. Following the addition of Li2S6, the binding energy of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 shows a more noticeable change along the lower direction, supporting the higher electron density at the center Ni and further resulting in the formation of strong chemical interactions between Li2S6 and Ni sites. Assemble Li2S6 symmetric cells to explore the catalytic capabilities of these samples. As shown in Fig. 4c, three pairs of redox peaks were observed in different samples, demonstrating superiority in transforming various polysulfides (Table S3). Compared with the other samples, M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 showed the highest peak response current, peak potential, as well as the smallest peak separations. This outcome indicates that M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 can successfully carry out the effective transformation of LiPSs, which promotes the conversion rate and reversibility toward sulfur. Coin-type LiS batteries with different cathodes are shown in cyclic voltammetry (CV) plots in Fig. 4d with a sweep rate of 0.1 mV s−1 spanning the 1.7–2.8 V potential window. Peak C (2.3 V) and Peak B (2.0 V) of the M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S electrode correspond to the process of S8 to Li2Sn and further reduction to insoluble Li2S/Li2S2, respectively. The oxidation peaks correspond to the process of Li2S/Li2S2 to Li2Sn and the subsequent conversion to S8. M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S exhibits the largest current response and the smallest polarization potential difference as well. Tafel curves representing different stages were used to assess the capacity of various samples to promote LiPSs conversion. As seen in Fig. 4e and Fig. S13, M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S delivers the lower Tafel slope value (106 mV dec−1) compared with Ni3Fe (172 mV dec−1), L-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S (144 mV dec−1) and H-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S (120 mV dec−1), demonstrating the advantages of the reduction process. In addition, Fig. 4f exhibits M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S a faster reaction rate (64.2 mV dec−1) in the oxidation process. The findings demonstrate that M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 promotes the reduction of Li2Sn in addition to having an advantage in the oxidation process. CV of various sweep speeds was used to compare the Li+ diffusion of several samples. Fig. 4g displays the CV curves with the M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S cathode at different scanning speeds. The matching peak current rises as the scanning rate does. The diffusion coefficients of each electrode were then further determined using the conventional Randles-Sevcik equation following the CV curves of other samples in Fig. S14 (1) I p = 2.69 × 10 5 n 3 / 2 A D L i + 1 / 2 C L i + v 1 / 2 The peak current is denoted by I p, the number of electrons in the reaction is expressed as n, A stands for the electrode area (0.785 cm2), and the Li+ diffusion coefficient is represented as D Li+, the Li+ concentration in the electrolyte is regarded as C Li+, and the scan rate is denoted by v. Fig. S15 manifests the corresponding relationship between the square root of scan rate v 1/2 and peak current I p of different cathodes. Both the oxidation and reduction peaks showed the greatest fitting slopes in M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S. Fig. 4h shows the corresponding Li+ diffusion coefficient, in which M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S exhibits a greater coefficient with 4 × 10−11 cm2 S−1 and 1.32 × 10−10 cm2 S−1, showing that M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 is more conducive to lithium-ion diffusion and promotes reaction kinetics. To investigate the mechanism underlying the elevated redox kinetics, electrochemical impedance spectra were obtained. Due to the excellent electrical conductivity of the modified heterostructure, the M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S cell had the lowest charge-transfer resistance, as shown in Fig. 4i. And the corresponding equivalent circuit of EIS is shown in Fig. S16. Consequently, charge transfer was encouraged and the transformation dynamics were enhanced. The resistance of the solid Li2S2/Li2S passivation layer formed during cycling was linked to the emergence of an extra semicircle in the high-frequency region following the cycles. To illustrate the catalytic properties of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 as a multifunctional catalyst in different reaction steps, the effects of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 on Li2S were further evaluated. Fig. 5 a, b and Fig. S17 compare the constant current discharge curve at 2.05 V, which can be fitted into three parts: reduction of Li2S8, reduction of Li2S6, and deposition of Li2S. Nucleation capacity is related to the area under the fitted curve. M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 showed the earliest time response (5.9 min) and showed a capacity of 89.7 mA h g−1. Compared with Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7, Ni3Fe represents a slower response time (10.3 min) and a lower capacity (32.7 mA h g−1). Different contents of Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 have different effects on the nucleation of Li2S. H-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 showed a relatively large current response time (9.7 min) and larger capacity (77.3 mA h g−1), while L-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 showed the latest response time (15.4 min) due to poor LiPSs adsorption. Furthermore, the current–time response (Fig. S18) was fitted using four classical electrochemical deposition models: 2DP (2D progressive nucleation), 2DI (2D instantaneous nucleation), 3DP (3D progressive nucleation), and 3DI (3D instantaneous nucleation) [56,57]. The t m corresponding to the peak current on the potentiostatic curve can be acquired by the following (2) t m = 2 π A k 2 1 / 3 A represents the nucleation rate constant, while k denotes the growth rate in the above Equation. It can be shown that Ni3Fe exhibits a mixed mode of 2DI-3DP by comparing the current curves of various samples. Upon generating a heterogeneous structure, it exhibits a propensity to convert to 3DP-3DI even though no nucleation mode adjustment is accomplished (Fig. 5c). The findings demonstrated that the formation of heterogeneous structures impacted the deposition pattern of Li2S and further encouraged its nucleation. To directly observe the deposition form and morphology of Li2S products, the battery was disassembled after a deposition test on carbon paper and the SEM test was conducted in Fig. 5e. The surface of the Ni3Fe/M-Ni3ZnC0.7 electrode is almost completely covered by transverse and solid materials, and there is a certain gap structure between the materials. However, sparsely deposited Li2S solid can be observed on the Ni3Fe electrode, indicating that M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 delivers highly efficient Li2S deposition behavior. In addition, the decomposition process of Li2S is also compared in Fig. 5f and Fig. S19. Among them, M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 shows the largest peak current response and the largest integral area under the curve, which indicates the effectiveness of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 as a bidirectional catalyst and reduces the reaction energy barrier in the oxidation process. Ni3Fe exhibited nearly no correlation peak of Li2S decomposition, which suggests that it has limited catalytic activity for Li2S dissociation. In summary, heterostructure formation aided in promoting the efficient nucleation and development of Li2S while facilitating the decomposition process. To capture real-time information on the dynamic process of polysulfide evolution, the dynamic evolution of dissolved LiPSs was measured by in situ UV–vis measurement [58,59]. Fig. 6 b, e shows that the discharge time of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S is longer, and the positive electrode of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S has a higher specific discharge capacity during the reduction process. Fig. 6c, f further contrasts the differences on M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S and Ni3Fe/S in the reduction process by examining the absorbance change. Absorbance at 420, 480 and 560 nm corresponds to the characteristic wavelengths of Li2S4, Li2S6 and Li2S8, respectively. In contrast to Ni3Fe/S, M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S showed an increase in absorbance at 5% DOD of various wavelength compounds, showing the rapid dissolution of LiPSs. Additionally, the absorbance exhibits a further decrease at 40% DOD, which results from the continued interaction of dissolved LiPSs with the conductive network [60,61]. Notably, the Li2S2-related LiPSs disproportionation process is responsible for the rise in low-order polysulfide concentrations at about 60% DOD. The absorbance alterations of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S at the conclusion of the reduction procedure also show the presence of the disproportionation reaction. On the other hand, Ni3Fe/S exhibited delayed kinetic behavior and extreme hysteresis throughout the reaction. In conclusion, the disproportionation reaction occurs throughout the whole reaction process. The reaction electron channel is created by the regulation of electrons at the heterogeneous interface, which influences the affinity for polysulfide and enhances the reaction kinetics. Theoretical calculations investigated the impact of the development of heterostructure on the D-band center in more detail. Fig. 7 a–c compares the differences in the projected density of states (PDOS) of different samples, and Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 demonstrates wider peaks compared with Ni3Fe and Ni3ZnC0.7, indicating a higher level of orbital hybridization. Also, Fig. S20 examines the D-band levels of several samples in further detail. The findings indicate the construction of Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 improves the D-band center (−2.38 eV) in contrast to Ni3ZnC0.7 (−3.12 eV), boosting the interaction with LiPSs. The greatest interaction with LiPSs was indicated by the most upwardly shifted D-band of Ni3Fe (−1.43 eV). The improvement of the D-band center in heterojunctions is mainly achieved by adjusting the electronic structure. Strong interfacial coupling in the heterostructure can increase the interfacial electron transfer and cause the D-band center to shift by forming an embedded electric field, promoting electron rearrangement in the hybrid catalyst. Additionally, a comparison was made regarding the binding energies of various polysulfides on various samples, the corresponding adsorption models were exhibited in Figs. S21–S23. Fig. S24 shows that the binding energy of various polysulfides on Ni3ZnC0.7 is the lowest, indicating the poor adsorption capacity towards LiPSs. The creation of Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 raises the binding energy even more, considerably boosting the adsorption capacity of various polysulfides. With the increase of Fe content in the synthesis process, Ni3Fe showed the highest binding energy among the three samples. Moreover, Fig. 7d confirms the reaction kinetic benefits with Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 in a variety of redox processes by calculating the free energy while taking into consideration an assortment of intermediate states (S8, Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4, Li2S2, and Li2S). Ni3Fe demonstrated a lower reaction energy (0.54 eV) barrier than Ni3ZnC0.7 (0.67 eV) at the high-order polysulfide transformation stage due to the strong adsorption towards polysulfides. After forming a heterogeneous interface, Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 achieved faster reaction kinetics and a lower reaction barrier (0.49 eV) by establishing an adsorption-diffusion-conversion channel path. The conversion process from Li2S2 to Li2S is often considered to be the rate-limiting step in the reduction process, and Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 still shows a reduced reaction barrier (0.37 eV) compared to Ni3Fe (0.44 eV) and Ni3ZnC0.7 (0.59 eV). Then, the decomposition energy barrier of Li2S in different samples during oxidation was investigated. As seen in Fig. 7e, Ni3ZnC0.7 (−0.25 eV) has a lower oxidation energy barrier than Ni3Fe (−0.21 eV), which encourages the breakdown of Li2S during the oxidation process, enhancing the reaction kinetics. In particular, the formation of heterogeneous interfaces makes Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 (0.11 eV) highlight the smallest reaction barrier, and advantage the dynamics significantly. Subsequently, Fig. 7f, g and Table S4 examine the breaking energy of the LiS bond in various samples. It is evident that Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 further lowers the LiS bond energy with the length of the LiS bond of Li2S8 (2.7 Å) and Li2S4 (2.94 Å), facilitating the transition of polysulfide in comparison to Ni3Fe and Ni3ZnC0.7. The aforementioned findings demonstrate that the formation of heterogeneous interfaces enhances the D-band center, increases the adsorption towards polysulfides, and lowers the reaction barrier. These findings demonstrate the effective bidirectional catalytic behavior of Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 in LiS batteries. According to the experimental and calculation results, Fig. 7h shows the reaction mechanism in the redox process of LiS batteries. The formation of the heterogeneous interface effectively regulates the electronic structure, optimizes the D-band center, and enables fast, balanced redox reactions of LiPSs. Specifically, the participating electrons could shift from the d orbital to the LUMO energy level of sulfur as a result of the d orbital of Ni3Fe hybridizing with the 2p orbital of sulfur species. The excessively high binding strength in the high d band causes slow desorption and catalytic activity in the sulfur reduction reaction. Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 strategically placing the D-band center at the middle of HOMO and LUMO between each sulfur species, allowing for a balanced quick oxidation and reduction process. 3 Conclusions In summary, the optimized Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 was built to clarify the thermodynamic development process and examine the connection between the heterogeneous interface and the D-band center. Combining the experimental with the theoretical calculation results, the heterogeneous interface serves as the active site to further promote the electron transfer and improve the catalytic activity, thus reducing the reaction energy barrier. Simultaneously, the shifted D-band center further increases the affinity of Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 towards polysulfide and weakens the bonding energy of the LiS bond, which proves the effectiveness of the modulated adsorption as well as bidirectional catalytic behavior of Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 in LiS batteries. As a result, the LiS batteries with the cathode of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S deliver impressive long-term cycling stability with a capacity retention of 0.062% per cycle after 500 cycles at 1.0 C. This work verifies the feasibility of the strategy of influencing energy band structure through interface engineering and provides guidance for designing heterogeneous catalysts with high catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: The polysulfide shuttle effect critically hinders lithium-sulfur (LiS) battery development, therefore, the design of heterogeneous interface engineering with “adsorption-catalysis” functions for polysulfide conversion has garnered considerable attention. However, the exploration of the intricate relationship between key electronic properties and catalytic activity at such interfaces remains a challenge. Additionally, a comprehensive understanding of the thermodynamic growth mechanisms for heterostructure materials is lacking. Herein, a Ni-based homologous structure was precisely constructed via thermodynamic control, with a specific focus on optimizing the interface design. The theoretical results show that the heterostructures with adjustable composition realize the appropriate upward shift to the D-band, improving the affinity towards polysulfide, and further reducing the reaction energy barrier. On this basis, the relationship between interface design and the D-band center, as well as catalytic performance, was established. Specifically, M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7 accomplishes the electron enrichment at the interface, supporting the further diffusion of polysulfides, and lowering the LiS bond energy, performing the bidirectional catalytic transformation of polysulfides. As a result, the LiS batteries with the cathode of M-Ni3Fe/Ni3ZnC0.7/S deliver rate performances of discharge capacity of 514 mA h g−1 at 5.0 C. This understanding of the D-band and interfacial design provides a framework for LiS catalyst optimization.
